utterances.utterance: Of course.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: But it was like poise and beauty and what's wrong with that?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Nothing at all.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Or were you homecoming queen?

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: Never!

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Why not?

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: I did not follow in my wonderful mom's footsteps.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Not enough boys.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: No, not enough boys, not enough beauty and not good enough grades.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Not enough boys.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: So, you know, I wouldn't won in Michigan.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I don't believe. I don't you.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: All right. Let's put up the billboard. They are worried that people's feelings might be hurt in California if they are called a stoner because pot is legal, recreational pot there and an eight other states so they are saying, you know, don't use that word, it's a little bit -- it's a little bit offensive. Call the person a nurse, call them a police officer, call them what they are supposed to be called.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: yes. I didn't think stoners got offended. I think they are pretty chill, but what does smoking marijuana feel like, Martha?

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: I wouldn't know.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, me neither! So I don't really know what being stone feels like so I can't really understand the offense taken. Is it like a feeling in the head like stoned?

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: Well, it supposed to mean that you are lazy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You're lazy.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: And that you are unproductive.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Is that what happens when you smoke pot?

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: Apparently.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Is that what you've heard?

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: That's what I've heard? You want to trap me here?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: I feel like I'm being in trap. That's what I've heard.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: But you know, the NIH study -- NIH studies -- not stoned, I just can't talk. No.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You're stoned, aren't you?

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: Said that it lowers productivity, lower graduation rates, negative impact on attention, learning and memory. So I wouldn't mess around with that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes. Pot is definitely bad, say no to drugs, kids. But listen, now pot the industry is trying to make it a good thing.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Because you know, people are buying it and they want to make money. So you know, stoner, they said forget stoners. MACCALLUM: Right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So I guess that's the slogan.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: I want them to do like I got milk thing with someone with a joint in their mouth may be. Got pot?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: A joint?

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: What do you think? Got pot?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What's a joint? I like it.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: It will be on billboards everywhere. Thanks, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Welcome.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: Good to see you. So, coming up here, this very serious topic to end the story with tonight. Hillary Clinton now saying that the woman who accused Brett Kavanaugh of attempted sexual assault deserves due process. Juanita Broaddrick, one of Bill Clinton's accusers, wants to respond to that and she's here now.

utterances.speaker: HILLARY CLINTON, FORMER SECRETARY OF STATE
utterances.utterance: Well, I think that you have to take each of these situations sort of on their own merits.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: So Hillary Clinton is now weighing in on the Kavanaugh controversy saying that his accuser Christine Blasey Ford deserves the benefit of the doubt, an investigation and due process. Watch.

utterances.speaker: RACHEL MADDOW, HOST, MSNBC
utterances.utterance: You had concerns at the time? Your husband had concerns at the time he never really had due process to defend himself from allegations like this. Have we learned anything over the years about due process not just for the accusers but also for the accused?

utterances.speaker: CLINTON
utterances.utterance: Well, I think that you have to take each of the situations on their own merits. And what we have today is a process that has been rushed, that has been deliberately opaque. Yes, there should be due process for everyone involved.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: My next guest takes some issue with those comments. Juanita Broaddrick says Hillary Clinton had a far different response when she came forward in the 1990s accusing former President Bill Clinton of raping her while running for governor of Arkansas in 1978. Here now exclusively tonight is Juanita Broaddrick. Juanita, good to see you. Thanks for being here. What goes through your mind when you hear her talk about due process and fairness for the accused and the accuser?

utterances.speaker: JUANITA BROADDRICK, ACCUSED BILL CLINTON OF SEXUAL MISCONDUCT
utterances.utterance: The first thing you think about is she didn't give it to me, she didn't give it to Kathleen Willie or Paula Jones. She didn't give it to any of us. She is asking for things that she denied the victims of her husband.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: And you also say that not only did she not acknowledge what you were accusing her husband of but that she intimidated you. And this is a sound bite, a clip from an interview that you did while back, explaining that, I think it was the day after you claimed you were raped by her husband and what her exchange was with you. Watch this.

utterances.speaker: BROADDRICK
utterances.utterance: She grabbed a hold of my arm and my hand and she pulls me into her and she says with this very angry look on her face, which had been so pleasant second before. And in a low voice says, do you understand everything you do? And that frightened me. At that moment -- and I have to go by what I felt then and the look that she gave me, I felt like she knew--

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: That he raped you?

utterances.speaker: BROADDRICK
utterances.utterance: Yes. And that she was telling me to keep quiet.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: You felt she was warning you to shut up?

utterances.speaker: BROADDRICK
utterances.utterance: Yes. She was so nice when she first said it to me. I was at a fundraiser that I had taken information up there. I was never going to stay for that. But she caught me before I left. And she comes up friendly and says, you know, Bill and I are just appreciative of everything you do. And then her voice changed and that is when she said what she did. It frightened me, Martha. It really did.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: You also say that when you look back at all of that period when you were making your claims that Dianne Feinstein was among those who refused to even read your deposition. So what do you think about of all of this now?

utterances.speaker: BROADDRICK
utterances.utterance: Yes. It's absurd. Not one Democrat would look at my deposition with the independent counsel.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: Why not?

utterances.speaker: BROADDRICK
utterances.utterance: Not one of them that consider--

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: What was the reason you were given? I'm sorry.

utterances.speaker: BROADDRICK
utterances.utterance: My gosh, it was absolute -- they didn't have -- they did not want to know about it. Just like Senator Ted Stevens said when he was in the committee, he said, I don't care if he raped her, got up and shot her dead. You're not going to get the vote.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: My--

utterances.speaker: BROADDRICK
utterances.utterance: So that was in the shipper's book sell out.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: Incredible. You know, you talk about how long ago your allegation was. It's only about four years different I think than the allegation against Brett Kavanaugh right now.

utterances.speaker: BROADDRICK
utterances.utterance: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: And you tweeted out "If the want FBI to go back that far--

utterances.speaker: BROADDRICK
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: -- basically let's investigate my situation as well." Right?

utterances.speaker: BROADDRICK
utterances.utterance: Exactly. Why not? You know, everybody says it was litigated and adjudicated. My case was never litigated. It was never adjudicated. It never went to court. I was never discredited at all.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: So let me ask you this. When you hear the parameters that are being set, they really want to the vote next week. What do you think about this woman, this accuser? Does she deserve more than she is getting right now from the senators in terms of speaking her mind or what they have offered her appropriate in your mind?

utterances.speaker: BROADDRICK
utterances.utterance: I feel like it's very appropriate. I feel like she could come Monday or let them come to her and let her tell her story. If they feel like there is more investigation that needs to be done, do it. But I think she should come and tell her story.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: You think about on your case and the Bill Clinton case, obviously, you know, so much have changed. Now we are in the Me Too movement. It's almost like it's completely opposite. Because back then, no one, you know, so many people refused to believe you. Now--

utterances.speaker: BROADDRICK
utterances.utterance: I know.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: -- it feels like you can make an accusation and everyone is supposed to believe you. What do you think about that?

utterances.speaker: BROADDRICK
utterances.utterance: I think the Me Too organization is for liberal women or liberal men that have been sexual assaulted. I don't think it includes the Clinton victims at all. I don't think they want us in that. Me Too may help some people. But it certainly has no advantage for me.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: You know, I think it's a good lesson because we do need to look at the situations--

utterances.speaker: BROADDRICK
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: -- with an open mind and we have to understand that lives get destroyed on both sides of the equation in terms of the guilty party and who the innocent party is. You know, what would be your message for her tonight as she contemplates whether or not she should go to that hearing on Monday?

utterances.speaker: BROADDRICK
utterances.utterance: She needs to think exactly what happened. Was it really Brett Kavanaugh that she can remember? She needs to get her story straight and be able to recount. I can't imagine being a 15-year-old girl and not telling anyone about it.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: So that surprises you, that she didn't share it with anyone? You shared it with several people?

utterances.speaker: BROADDRICK
utterances.utterance: Yes, yes, yes. I know I was 35 at the time. But it's just a young girl. I can't imagine her not going home, telling her parents, telling someone.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: Juanita, thank you. Great to see you tonight. That is our Story for this evening on Wednesday night. Send me a tweet at Martha MacCallum using the hash tag TheStory.
